title: Diffraction Efficiency of a Ramp Phase Grating
description: Calculate the diffraction efficiency for the m=+1 and all other orders of a ramp phase grating using a given transmittance function.
insight: Diffraction efficiency can be derived using Fourier coefficients for a ramp phase grating, where only the m=1 order contributes significantly.
question_text: Find the diffraction efficiency for the m=+1 and all other orders of a ramp phase grating with the given transmittance function: $$T(x) = e^{jKx}$$.
hint: Evaluate the Fourier coefficients using integration and simplify using symmetry properties.

steps: Start with the transmittance function: $$T(x) = e^{jKx}$$.
Write the expression for the Fourier coefficient: $$C_m = \frac{1}{\Lambda} \int_0^{\Lambda} e^{jKx} e^{-jmKx} dx$$.
Simplify the exponent: $$= \frac{1}{\Lambda} \int_0^{\Lambda} e^{j(1-m)Kx} dx$$.
Evaluate for $$m = 1$$: $$C_1 = \frac{1}{\Lambda} \int_0^{\Lambda} e^{0} dx = 1$$.
Evaluate for $$m \neq 1$$: The integral evaluates to zero after simplification.
Square the coefficients to get diffraction efficiency: $$\eta_{+1} = |C_1|^2 = 1$$ and $$\eta_{m \neq 1} = |C_m|^2 = 0$$.
Conclusion: Only the first order (m=1) has nonzero diffraction efficiency.

title: Thick vs Thin Hologram Classification
description: Determine whether a hologram is classified as thick or thin based on laser parameters and holographic emulsion properties.
insight: A hologram is classified as thick if the Q-factor is significantly larger than 1, while a thin hologram has a Q-factor much smaller than 1.
question_text: Two green lasers (550 nm) expose a holographic plate with an emulsion thickness of 5µm and refractive index of 1.6. One laser fires directly at the plate; the other is off-axis by 66°. After exposing the plate, the on-axis laser is again fired into the resulting pattern. Is this hologram thick or thin?
hint: Use the Q-factor formula: $$Q = \frac{2\pi \lambda t}{n d^2 \cos(\theta_0)}$$, where $$\lambda$$ is the wavelength, $$t$$ is the emulsion thickness, $$n$$ is the refractive index, and $$d$$ is the spacing.

steps: Use the Q-factor formula: $$Q = \frac{2\pi \lambda t}{n d^2 \cos(\theta_0)}$$.
Substitute the given values: $$\lambda = 550 \times 10^{-9} \text{ m}$$, $$t = 5 \times 10^{-6} \text{ m}$$, $$n = 1.6$$, and $$d = 6.02 \times 10^{-7} \text{ m}$$.
Evaluate the numerator: $$2\pi (550 \times 10^{-9})(5 \times 10^{-6})$$.
Evaluate the denominator: $$(1.6)(6.02 \times 10^{-7})^2 (\cos(\theta_0))$$, where $$\cos(\theta_0)$$ is assumed to be 1 for simplicity.
Simplify the Q-factor.
If $$Q \gg 1$$, the hologram is thick. If $$Q \ll 1$$, it is thin.
Conclusion: The calculated Q-factor is much larger than 1, indicating a thick hologram.
